intro: Acacia xerophila, commonly known as the desert wattle, is a shrub native to arid regions of Australia. It is characterized by its small, leathery leaves and yellow flowers that bloom in spring. The plant has adapted to survive in harsh, dry environments through its deep root system and reduced leaf surface area. Its seeds are encased in a hard pod, which helps protect them from desiccation. Acacia xerophila plays an important role in stabilizing soil and providing habitat for desert wildlife.

Its genus is Acacia, a group of shrubs and trees known for their distinctive umbrella-like clusters of small flowers and commonly used in various ecological and commercial contexts. Its species is Acacia xerophila, a specific type of acacia adapted to arid environments, distinguished by its drought-resistant traits and unique morphological features.

It is commonly found in the arid and semi-arid regions of the state, particularly in the western and central areas. This plant thrives in sandy soils and is adapted to the harsh climatic conditions of the region. It is often seen in shrublands and along coastal dunes. Its distribution is closely linked to the unique ecological zones of Western Australia.
